body:
> And validator is supposed to validate strings.

No, it is not. For example, if you have a model Recipe and you are using ingredients as nested attributes, you can do something like:

    validates :ingredients, length: 1..10

Someone also mentioned an example with hstore.

>  If i need to validate/typecast them before validator - this is wrong behavior.

You are not supposed to typecast because of the validator, you are supposed to typecast simply because it is the correct thing to do. In my opinion, the fact you can do this is wrong:

    post = Post.new
    post.title = [1,2,3]
    post.title #=> [1,2,3]

You should not get an array back. It should be typecast to a string once you set it (or raise an exception).
